title: 115_hr5270
content: The "Electricity Reliability and Fuel Security Act" includes a Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units under SEC. 45T. The Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units under SEC. 45T allows a taxpayer who owns or leases such units to claim a credit equal to 30% of qualified expenses or $13 multiplied by the unit's capacity rating in kilowatts, whichever is lower. The term 'coal-powered electric generation unit' refers to a unit that uses coal for at least 75% of electricity production. 'Qualified expenses' include costs for operation and maintenance, excluding coal expenses. Public entities can transfer the tax credit for these units. The term 'qualified expenses' refers to costs for operating and maintaining a coal-powered electric generation unit, excluding coal expenses. Public entities have the option to transfer the tax credit for these units. The tax credit for eligible projects can be transferred by the eligible project partner instead of the qualified public entity. The term 'qualified public entity' refers to a Federal, State, or local government. The term 'qualified public entity' includes Federal, State, or local government entities, mutual or cooperative electric companies, and not-for-profit electric utilities that have received a loan. The term 'eligible project partner' refers to any person responsible for operating, maintaining, or repairing a coal-powered electric generation unit. The term 'eligible project partner' includes individuals involved in operating, maintaining, repairing, providing coal, financing, or leasing a coal-powered electric generation unit. The term 'eligible project partner' includes individuals involved in operating, maintaining, repairing, providing coal, financing, or leasing a coal-powered electric generation unit. Special rules apply to partnerships for determining tax credits at the partnership level. The term 'eligible project partner' includes any partner of the partnership. Tax credits are taken into account in the first taxable year of the eligible project partner after the qualified public entity's taxable year. The eligible project partner includes any partner of the partnership. Tax credits are accounted for in the first taxable year of the eligible project partner following the qualified public entity's taxable year. Any benefit from an election under this subsection is not considered a private business use for private use rules. Basis adjustment is made if a credit is allowed for a coal-powered electric project. The section provides details on the basis adjustment for a credit allowed on a coal-powered electric generation unit. It specifies that the section applies to taxable years between December 31, 2017, and January 1, 2023. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to Section 501(c)(12)(I) to include the new section. The credit can be used against the alternative minimum tax. The text discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code related to a credit for coal-powered electric generation units for taxable years between December 31, 2017, and January 1, 2023. Amendments include allowing the credit against the alternative minimum tax and making clerical changes to the code. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a new clause for the credit determined under section 45T. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a new clause for the credit determined under section 45T for coal-powered electric generation units.
